texts.definition: Rewards in a game which are only given to one player.
markups: <style="Definition">Rewards in a game which are only given to one player.</style>

Games are typically set up so that there are rewards for certain actions or the completion of specific challenges. When these rewards are only given to one player - regardless if several players contributed - the rewards are <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style>.

In single-player games the rewards are naturally <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style>. For example, in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tetris">Tetris</link></style> it is the player who performs the actions and fills in the rows who gets the reward.

Many multiplayer games that pitch players against each other have <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style>. For example, in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style> the player that performs a successful attack conquers the area even though there might be several other players supporting this action with their own armies. Likewise, rewards associated with killing an enemy in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style> or death-match games of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quake%20series">Quake</link></style> are given to the player that dealt the final damage even if other players may have caused more total damage.

Like other types of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, designing <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> requires deciding on what specifically makes up the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> and when they should be given. Quite naturally, all <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> but they can be used for various reasons in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. First, they can increase <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conflicts">Conflicts</link></style> by giving clear indications between the difference of winning or losing specific gameplay activities. They can also decrease motivation or make more complex <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>.

For apparent reasons, the same <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> cannot both be <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> and <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>. However, <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style> can make <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style> into individual ones if players can renounce their right to parts of the <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>.

Rather obviously, <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> is a type of <style="Link"><link="rewards">Reward</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> can cause <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> if a player can see that others, or a collective, could have greater benefit of the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> than the player could have. One such example is games in which there exists <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> but team members are in <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> with each other over <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style>, this not only causes <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> but also <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>.

When combined with <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="collaborative-actions">Collaborative Actions</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Individual Rewards</style> give rise to <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>.
